description:
Tubulinosema ratisbonensis is a species of microsporidian, a group of obligate intracellular parasites that infect a wide range of eukaryotic hosts, including insects, other invertebrates, and even some vertebrates. Microsporidians are characterized by their unique spore structure, which includes a coiled polar tube that is used to inject the infective sporoplasm into the host cell.

Tubulinosema ratisbonensis was first identified in the beetle Tenebrio molitor, commonly known as the mealworm, and has since been found to infect other beetle species as well. The spores of T. ratisbonensis are oval-shaped and measure approximately 3-4 μm in length. The polar tube is relatively short, typically less than 10 μm in length.

The life cycle of T. ratisbonensis involves the invasion of host cells, typically gut epithelial cells, where the parasites multiply and ultimately form new spores that are released and can infect other host cells or be transmitted to new hosts. The impact of T. ratisbonensis infection on its beetle hosts can vary, ranging from asymptomatic to significant reductions in growth, reproduction, and survival, depending on factors such as the host species, age, and the intensity of the infection.

Tubulinosema ratisbonensis is of interest to researchers studying the ecology and evolution of host-parasite interactions, as well as the potential use of microsporidians as biological control agents for insect pests.
